docs.title: Welcome to Electro Gamma
docs.text: At Electro Gamma, we are passionate about Linux, Open Source Software, Open Source Hardware, and the exciting world of electronics. Whether you are a developer, maker, or enthusiast, we provide a variety of tutorials, resources, and guides to help you explore and build with open technologies.

docs.title: Our Focus
docs.text: We cover a range of topics to cater to beginners and advanced users alike:

docs.title: 1. Linux and Open Source Software
docs.text: Linux is the foundation of our work, and we believe in the power of open source to foster innovation. Our tutorials help you: - Install and configure Linux on various devices, including desktops, laptops, and single-board computers. - Learn about post-installation steps for popular Linux distributions like Ubuntu, Fedora, and Debian. - Explore open source tools for productivity, security, and development.

docs.title: 2. Open Source Hardware
docs.text: The revolution in open hardware is transforming how we approach electronics. We focus on: - Arduino: Dive into the world of microcontrollers with Arduino, learning how to build everything from simple sensors to complex projects. - Raspberry Pi: A powerful yet affordable platform for prototyping, home automation, and educational projects. Learn how to set up and build various projects with Raspberry Pi. - ESP32 and ESP8266: Explore IoT with these low-cost, Wi-Fi-enabled microcontrollers that are perfect for smart devices.

docs.title: 3. Electronics and DIY Projects
docs.text: Building things with your hands is at the core of the maker movement. We provide guides and projects for: - Electronic circuits: Learn the basics of electronics, from resistors and capacitors to transistors and ICs. - DIY projects: Create gadgets like smart lights, security systems, and custom sensors using open hardware and open source software.

docs.title: 4. Community and Collaboration
docs.text: Open source is all about collaboration. We believe in sharing knowledge and contributing to the community. You can: - Contribute to our open source projects on GitHub. - Follow our tutorials to replicate projects and build your own creations. - Join our discussions on forums and GitHub issues to connect with fellow enthusiasts.

docs.title: Check Out Our YouTube Channel
docs.text:
We regularly post tutorials, reviews, and projects on our Electro Gamma YouTube Channel. Subscribe to stay updated with our latest content on Linux, Arduino, Raspberry Pi, and more!

docs.text:
We welcome anyone interested in open technology, whether you are a beginner or an expert. Stay tuned for more tutorials, guides, and projects, and don’t forget to contribute your ideas!

Together, we can build a future where technology is open, accessible, and collaborative.

docs.title: Arduino Analog Read Example
docs.text: This example reads the value from an analog sensor and prints it to the Serial Monitor. It demonstrates how to use the analog input pins on Arduino.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
const int sensorPin = A0; // pin connected to the analog sensor

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(9600); // initialize serial communication
}

void loop() {
  int sensorValue = analogRead(sensorPin);
  Serial.println(sensorValue); // print the sensor value
  delay(1000); // wait for a second
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• analogRead(): Reads the analog value from the specified pin (0-1023) where 0 represents 0V and 1023 represents the reference voltage (usually 5V or 3.3V).
  • Serial.begin(): Initializes serial communication at the specified baud rate.
  • Serial.println(): Outputs the value to the Serial Monitor for viewing.

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text:
• Ensure that your sensor is connected to an analog input pin (A0-A5) on the Arduino.
  • Adjust the delay to match the desired data sampling rate.

docs.title: Arduino Blink Example
docs.text: The Blink sketch is a simple Arduino program that blinks an LED connected to a digital pin. This is often the first program written when learning Arduino.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
// the setup function runs once when you press reset or power the board
void setup() {
  // initialize digital pin LED_BUILTIN as an output.
  pinMode(LED_BUILTIN, OUTPUT);
}

// the loop function runs over and over again forever
void loop() {
  digitalWrite(LED_BUILTIN, HIGH);   // turn the LED on (HIGH is the voltage level)
  delay(1000);                       // wait for a second
  digitalWrite(LED_BUILTIN, LOW);    // turn the LED off by making the voltage LOW
  delay(1000);                       // wait for a second
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• pinMode(): Configures the specified pin to operate as an output. In this case, the onboard LED pin (LED_BUILTIN) is set as an output.
  • digitalWrite(): Sets the voltage level of a specified pin. HIGH turns the LED on, and LOW turns it off.
  • delay(): Pauses the program for the specified amount of time (in milliseconds). Here, it waits for 1 second between turning the LED on and off.

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text:
• The LED_BUILTIN constant refers to the onboard LED on many Arduino boards. It is usually connected to pin 13.
  • You can change the delay values to adjust the blink rate.

docs.title: Arduino Button Press Example
docs.text: This example demonstrates how to turn on an LED when a button is pressed. It uses a simple digital input to control a digital output.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
const int buttonPin = 2;    // pin connected to the button
const int ledPin = 13;      // pin connected to the LED

void setup() {
  pinMode(buttonPin, INPUT);
  pinMode(ledPin, OUTPUT);
}

void loop() {
  int buttonState = digitalRead(buttonPin);
  if (buttonState == HIGH) {
    digitalWrite(ledPin, HIGH); // turn the LED on
  } else {
    digitalWrite(ledPin, LOW);  // turn the LED off
  }
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• digitalRead(): Reads the state of a digital pin, which can be either HIGH or LOW.
  • if statement: Turns the LED on when the button is pressed and off when it is not.

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text:
• Use a pull-down resistor (e.g., 10kΩ) between the button pin and ground to ensure a clean signal.
  • Connect the button between the pin and 5V, and the pin will read HIGH when the button is pressed.

docs.title: Arduino Fade Example
docs.text: The Fade sketch gradually changes the brightness of an LED connected to a PWM-capable pin. This example demonstrates how to use PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) to control LED brightness.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
const int ledPin = 9; // pin connected to the LED

void setup() {
  pinMode(ledPin, OUTPUT);
}

void loop() {
  // Fade the LED in and out
  for (int brightness = 0; brightness <= 255; brightness++) {
    analogWrite(ledPin, brightness);
    delay(10);
  }
  for (int brightness = 255; brightness >= 0; brightness--) {
    analogWrite(ledPin, brightness);
    delay(10);
  }
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• analogWrite(): Sets a PWM value (0-255) to control the LED's brightness. A value of 0 means the LED is off, and 255 means it is fully on.
  • for loop: Gradually increases and decreases the PWM value to create a fading effect.

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text:
• The ledPin should be connected to a PWM-capable pin on your Arduino (e.g., pin 9).
  • The delay(10) function controls the speed of the fade effect.

docs.title: Arduino PWM Control Example
docs.text: This example demonstrates how to control the brightness of an LED using PWM. It gradually increases and decreases the LED's brightness.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
const int ledPin = 9; // pin connected to the LED

void setup() {
  pinMode(ledPin, OUTPUT);
}

void loop() {
  for (int i = 0; i < 256; i++) {
    analogWrite(ledPin, i);
    delay(10);
  }
  for (int i = 255; i >= 0; i--) {
    analogWrite(ledPin, i);
    delay(10);
  }
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• analogWrite(): Sets a PWM value (0-255) to control the brightness of the LED.
  • for loop: Increases and decreases the PWM value to create a fading effect.

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text:
• The ledPin should be connected to a PWM-capable pin (e.g., pin 9).
  • Adjust the delay to control the speed of the fade effect.

docs.title: Arduino Servo Control Example
docs.text: This example shows how to control a servo motor using Arduino. The servo sweeps back and forth.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
#include <Servo.h>

Servo myServo; // create a Servo object

void setup() {
  myServo.attach(9); // pin connected to the servo
}

void loop() {
  for (int pos = 0; pos <= 180; pos++) {
    myServo.write(pos);
    delay(15);
  }
  for (int pos = 180; pos >= 0; pos--) {
    myServo.write(pos);
    delay(15);
  }
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• Servo.h: Library for controlling servo motors.
  • myServo.attach(): Specifies the pin connected to the servo.
  • myServo.write(): Sets the servo position.

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text:
• Ensure the servo is connected to a PWM-capable pin (e.g., pin 9).
  • The delay(15) function controls the speed of the servo movement.

docs.title: MF253V Router Script
docs.text: This repository contains a Python script (Router.py) designed to interact with the MF253V router. The script allows you to manage and configure various settings such as Wi-Fi, blacklists, and network connections through HTTP requests.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Wi-Fi Management: Enable, disable, or configure Wi-Fi settings.
  • Blacklist Management: Add or remove devices from the router's blacklist.
  • Network Configuration: Set up network parameters such as IP addresses, DNS, etc.
  • Real-time Status: Retrieve real-time information about the router's status.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.x
  • Requests Library: Install using pip install requests

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
1. Clone this repository to your local machine: 
    git clone https://github.com/Electro-Gamma/Router-Scripts.git
  2. Navigate to the project directory: 
    cd Router-Scripts
  3. Install the required dependencies: 
    pip install -r requirements.txt
  4. Run the script: 
    python Router.py

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: The script may require you to configure certain parameters such as the router's IP address, username, and password. These can be set within the script file (Router.py).

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If you encounter any issues while using the script, please ensure that:

  1. The router's IP address is correctly configured.
  2. Your device is connected to the router's network.
  3. You have the necessary permissions to modify router settings.

docs.title: Contributions
docs.text: Contributions to this project are welcome! Please submit a pull request or open an issue to discuss your ideas.

docs.title: Arduino Blink Example
docs.text:
The following code is an example of the Arduino Blink sketch. It makes the onboard LED blink on and off with a 1-second interval.

// the setup function runs once when you press reset or power the board
void setup() {
  // initialize digital pin LED_BUILTIN as an output.
  pinMode(LED_BUILTIN, OUTPUT);
}

// the loop function runs over and over again forever
void loop() {
  digitalWrite(LED_BUILTIN, HIGH);   // turn the LED on (HIGH is the voltage level)
  delay(1000);                       // wait for a second
  digitalWrite(LED_BUILTIN, LOW);    // turn the LED off by making the voltage LOW
  delay(1000);                       // wait for a second
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• pinMode(): This function configures the specified pin to behave either as an input or an output.
  • digitalWrite(): It sets the specified pin to either HIGH or LOW voltage.
  • delay(): Pauses the program for the amount of time (in milliseconds) specified as the parameter.

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text:
• The LED_BUILTIN constant refers to the onboard LED pin number on Arduino boards.
  • The delay(1000) function makes the program wait for 1000 milliseconds (or 1 second) between switching the LED on and off.
